column3: Fundamental Concepts (e.g. takes up space, has mass, two objects cannot occupy the same place at the same time, matter is made up of atoms)
Mixtures

column4: Heterogeneous (a physical, not chemical combination -- like sand and marbles mixed together)
Separating Heterogeneous mixtures (e.g. separating aluminum and steel cans)

column3: Properties of Objects

column4: Density (when talking about an object made of many materials/compounds)

column3: Properties of Materials

column4: Density (when talking about a specific material, element, or compound/substance)
Solubility (ability of a substance to dissolve in another substance, the solvant)
Luster (light interation with crystals or minerals)

column3: Measurement

column4: Units (Questions about what units would be appropriate, or interpretations of units (e.g. pH of 2 is an acid)

column3: Environmental Effects on Properties (e.g. temperature -- hot or cold; lighting -- shadows, color; moisture -- wet or dry)
States of Matter (solids have definite shape and volume, etc.)
Changes of State
Changes
Chemistry

column4: Periodic Table, Properties of Elements in particular Groups/Columns.  Symbols for specific elements (e.g. Magnesium = Mg). Properties of elements (e.g. Element X has a melting point of..., one or more atoms of an element have the properties of that element, an element is identified by its number of protons, etc )
Atoms, components of atoms (e.g. nucleus, protons, neutrons, electrons) and the charge/masses/etc of these subatomic particles
Elements versus Molecules/Compounds (e.g. H is an element, H2O is a molecule)
Conservation of Mass -- the mass of the chemicals going into a reaction is the same as the mass of the chemicals leaving a reaction

column3: Forms of Energy, and Identifying Forms of Energy (energy exists in various forms: heat, electric, sound, chemical, mechanical, light)
Conservation of Energy -- in a closed system, energy is neither created nor destroyed, it only changes form.
Electricity

column4: Electrical Circuits (e.g. energy travels in a closed circuit)
Generation/Sources of Electrical Energy/Generators.  Also Solar, Nuclear, Natural Gas, Geothermal, Coal, etc. -> Electrical Energy

column3: Common energy-using devices, their USAGES, and how they convert energy (e.g. a stove converts electricity to thermal energy).  For converting to electrical energy, use ENG_ELEC_GENERATE
Potential Energy vs Kinetic Energy
Measurement of Energy
Converting Energy Between Forms (e.g. animals convert chemical energy (food) to heat and motion).  Conversion may not be 100% efficient, etc.

column4: Converting between energy forms (e.g. mechanical to electrical).  Sometimes paired with ENG_DEVICES

Inefficiencies in converting between energy forms/energy loss (e.g. a car is expected to travel 100km on a tank, but only travels 25km.  Where did the extra energy go?  Thermal loss/wind resistance/etc).  Perpetual motion machines can be here too.

column3: Interaction of Energy and Matter (e.g. water is evaporated by the Sun’s heat; a bulb is lit by means of electrical current)
Light

column4: Generic properties about light (Both a particle and a wave, etc).
Colour of objects in coloured light (this intersects with Absorption and Reflection, but is a specific kind of problem asked)
Refraction, Prisms, Spreading white light into component colours.
Speed of light, changes in a given medium

column3: Thermal Energy

column4: Generic properties about thermal energy (e.g. thermal energy represents atoms vibrating, temperature is a measure of thermal energy).

column5: Convection (e.g. a liquid or gas sqirling, causing high-termperature areas to heat low-temperature areas)
Radiation (electromagnetic radiation heating up an object, e.g. the Sun warming the Earth)
Induction (heating a metal/electrically conducting object by electromagnetic induction)

column3: Sound

column4: Generic properties about sound (Sound travels as longitudinal waves, sound moves outward in all directions, sound is vibrationsi in the air, etc).
Speed of sound, changes in a given medium
Doppler effect (increase/decrease frequency as you move to/from the source)

column3: Waves

column4: Generic properties about waves (waves exist in different forms (e.g. light, sound, pond ripples, etc).
Types of wave motion (e.g. transverse, compression)

column3: Gravity (force of gravity pulls objects towards the center of the Earth)
Friction (change in motion of a moving object)
Magnetism (attract/repel)
Mechanical energy (e.g. the position or direction of an object can be changed by pushing or pulling, application of force through simple machines such as pulleys, levers, and inclined planes)

column4: The position/direction of an object can be changed by pushing/pulling
Simple Machines (pulleys, levers, inclined planes, wedge, screw, wheel and axle)

column3: Forces and Objects (forces of gravity and magnetism affect objects through gasses, liquids, and solids)
Motion Problems (e.g. a train is moving at 20m/s over 100m of track, how long will it take to... etc)
Balanced Forces (e.g. if an object is acted on by two forces that are equal and opposite, then it will not move)
Momentum (the product of the mass and velocity of an object)
Newton's Laws of Motion

column4: Newton's 1st law (inertia): Objects in motion tend to stay in motion unless acted on by a force
Newton's 2nd law: The greater the mass of an object, the more force it will take to accelerate the object
Newton's 3rd law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.  (i.e. when you kick a ball, the ball applies an equal and opposite force on your foot)

column3: Air resistance (e.g. aerodynamics, parachutes generate air resistance to decelerate, etc.)
Lift (force used by airplanes to counteract gravity)
Velocity/Speed
Work (work is force over distance)
Power (power is work over time)
Pressure (force of something (including a solid, liquid, or gas) on another object)
Natural Cycles and Patterns (e.g. Seasons/daylight, weather changes, Earth /spinning/ around once every 24 hours, Earth /orbiting/ the sun, the time for the moon to orbit the Earth)
Time units and natural motion (second, minute, hour, week, month).  Time zones.

Apparent Celestial Motion (The Sun and other stars appear to move in a recognizable pattern both daily and seasonally from an observer on Earth, solar motion, lunar motion, motion of stars, motion of constellations)
Celestial Distances/Locations (Relative or absolute distances between sun, planets, other stars; closest star to Earth; planetary ordering, moon distance ordering, etc)

column4: Units for celestial distances (light year, astronomical unit)

column3: Planetary/Stellar Sizes (Relative or absolute sizes of stars, planets, and/or moons)
Planetary/Stellar Brightnesses/Apparent Brightness (Inverse square law, farther celestial objects are generally less bright unless they are very large or very reflective, reflectivity)
Planetary/Stellar Definitions and Features (e.g. the moon is full of craters, Venus has a dense atmosphere, Mars is red and has a minimal atmosphere, black holes are super dense, etc)

column4: Solar System definitions/features (e.g. asteroid belts, oort cloud, parts of a solar system/overall structure, etc)

column3: Instruments for astronomy (e.g. telescopes, cameras)
Causes of tides / lunar effects on tides
Lunar phases (full, new, waxing, waning)
Eclipses
Space Exploration
Search for extraterestrial life
Origin and development of universe.  Big bang, expansion, etc.
Orbits are elliptical.  Gravity causes objects to orbit each other.  Tidally locked orbits.
Weightlessness/Differences in weight due to gravitational pull/differences in gravitational pull due to the mass of a celestial object.
Weather

column4: Weather/Climate Definition (definition, the condition of the outside air at a particular moment)
Weather measurement (temperature, wind speed, form and amount of precipitation, sky conditions, e.g, cloudy, sunny)
Clouds, cloud types, formation of specific cloud types
The Water Cycle (evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff & groundwater)

column5: The Sun and the Water Cycle (Heat energy from the Sun powers the water cycle)

column4: Erosion, weathering, and deposition (interaction among air, water, land, gravity; soil is living and non-living material, wind erosion, ice wedging, weathering)

column5: Weathering (breaking down rocks, from weather or chemical or mechanical means -- e.g. wind, water, ice, plants, animals)
Erosion (moving sediment from broken rock, by e.g. wind, water, ice, gravity)
Deposition (moving sediment to a new place, e.g. formation of sand dunes)

column4: Extreme natural events (floods, fires, droughts, volcanic eruptions, hurricanes, tornadoes; positive & negative effects)
Geographic effects on weather (e.g. humidity from being near an ocean)
Climate of Specific Locations (e.g. place X has climate Y)

column3: Human Impacts

column4: How Humans Affect the Environment (Over time humans have changed their environment by cultivating crops and raising animals, creating shelter)
Human Impact's on the Environment (Humans alter environments in ways that can be either helpful or harmful for themselves and other organisms)

column5: Recycling (what kinds of materials are recyclable, the positive benefit of recycling)
Conservation (turning off the lights to use less electricity, water management/using less water, more fuel efficient vehicles, etc)

column4: Resources (use these categories to describe both the human impacts, as well as general properties/usages of these resources)

column5: renewable vs non-renewable, benefits of renewable resources
Fossil fuels (generic, not refering to a specific fossil fuel like oil/coal/natural gas)

column3: Soil

column4: Soil's role with plants/in an ecosystem

column3: Geology

column5: Formation (where/how are minerals likely to form)
Inferring properties about a LOCATION/ENVIRONMENT in the past based on the fossils that have been found in it
Inferring properties about a SPECIES in the past based on the fossils that have been found
Formation/Types of rock that fossils form/are preserved/found in
Index fossils / dating fossils / dating rocks using fossils

column4: Geological Formations/Structures, and how they were formed (e.g. how are caves formed).  Note this may be used in conjunction with the WEATHERING/EROSION labels.
Geological History (major geological events of the past)

column3: Outer Structure

column4: Lithosphere (the outtermost part of the earth, consisting of crust and upper mantle)
Hydrosphere (the oceans/water, content of oceans/freshwater bodies, relative sizes/etc)
Atmosphere (e.g. What is the atmosphere made out of?  What are the layers of the atmosphere? etc)

column3: Inner Structure

column4: Plate Techtonics, Continental Drift, Mountain Formation (non-volcanic), Volcanoe formation

column3: Cardinal Direction (e.g. north, east, south, west; measurement of this, e.g. compass)
Latitude/Longitude (and measurement of this, e.g. sextant)
Living vs Non-living (Nonliving things do not live and thrive)
Classification/Identification of living things (kingdoms,vertebrate/invertebrate, etc)
Tools for studying life (e.g. microscopes, dissection kits, etc)
Reproduction

column5: DNA (Generic properties: DNA encodes information about the organism, gene is the smallest unit of inheritable information, etc.)
Dominant/Recessive Genes, Crossing, Probability calculations for having particular traits

column4: Competition (some living things compete between members of their own species to reproduce)

column3: The Environment and Adaptation (senses, habitats, behavior, camouflage)

column5: Animal Adaptations (Each animal has different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction, migration)

column6: Structures (Particular animal characteristics are influenced by changing environmental conditions including: fat storage in winter, coat thickness in winter)

column7: hunting (e.g. sharp teeth, fast speed, etc)
defense (e.g. octopus ink, skunk odor, bright color, porcpine extends quills)

column6: Behaviors (Some animal behaviors are influenced by environmental conditions, e.g., nest building, hibernating, hunting, migrating, and communicating)

column5: Plant Adaptations (Each plant has different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction)

column4: Competition (Adaptations to be better at competing -- Individuals within a species may compete with each other for food, mates, space, water, and shelter in their environment, e.g. giraffe's long neck to get at the highest leaves)
Natural Selection (All individuals have variations, and because of these variations, individuals of a species may have an advantage in surviving and reproducing)

column3: Continuity of Life (life cycle, life span, offspring, reproduction)

column4: Plant Life Cycles/Stages (Each kind of plant goes through its own stages of growth and development that may include seed, young plant, and mature plant)
Plant Life Spans (The length of time from beginning of development to death of the plant is called its life span)
Animal Life Cycles/Stages (Each generation of animals goes through changes in form from young to adult, each kind of animal goes through its own stages of growth and development during its life span)
Animal Life Spans (The length of time from an animal’s birth to its death is called its life span. Life spans of different animals vary)

column5: Definition (Growth is the process by which plants and animals increase in size)
Growth Processes (Food supplies the energy and materials necessary for growth and repair.)

column3: Ecology/Interdependence (food web, producers, consumers, decomposers)

column4: Features of ecosystems/biomes (e.g. a forest has trees, a desert ecosystem has little water, classifying ecosystems based on their features.)

column5: Plant Producers (Green plants are producers because they provide the basic food supply for themselves and animals; Plants manufacture food by utilizing air, water, and energy from the Sun)
Animal Dependence/Consumers (All animals depend on plants. Some animals - predators - eat other animals - prey.  Herbivore/Carnivore/Omnivore)
Decomposers/Scavengers (Decomposers are living things that play a vital role in recycling nutrients)
The Sun and Food Chains (The Sun’s energy is transferred on Earth from plants to animals through the food; the Sun is the ultimate source of energy for nearly all living things on Earth)

column4: Ecological Succession (the evolution of a biological community over time.  primary succession/secondary succession/climax communities.  steps that ecosystems proceed in to take an essentially lifeless area (like a forest after a fire) and make it habitable again)

Population Dynamics (competition, predator/prey population interdependence, limited resource dependence, organisms are affected by the kinds and numbers of other organisms present, the availability of food and other resources)
Relationships between species (Predator/Prey, Parasitism, Mutualism, Commensalism)

Responses to Environmental Change (When the environment changes, needs may not be met. Some plants and animals survive and reproduce, and others die or move to new locations. E.g. human's destroy animal habitats, what will the animals most likely do)
Identifying Biotic/Abiotic Factors in Ecosystems (e.g. water is an abiotic (non-living) part of an ecosystem)

column3: The Carbon Cycle (carbon travels from the atmosphere into organisms/the Earth, then back to the atmosphere)
The Nitrogen Cycle (nitrogen in air converted to nitrates by lighting, brought to soil by rain, plants absorb from soil, animals eat plants, returns to soil as ammonia through droppings/decomposers)
Life Functions (breathing, growing, eating, food supply)

column4: Life Functions (All living things grow, take in nutrients, breathe, reproduce, and eliminate waste, and die; air, water, food)

column5: Essentials for animals (Animals need air, water, and food in order to live and thrive)

column6: Eating/Nutrition for animals (carbohydrates, fats, minerals, proteins, vitamins)

column5: Essentials for plants (Plants require air, water, nutrients, and light in order to live and thrive)

column4: Features and Functions (parts and their functions, e.g. a leaf is used for photosynthesis; An organism’s external physical features can enable it to carry out life functions in its particular environment)

column6: Senses (Senses can provide essential information regarding danger, food, mates, etc. to animals about their environment)
Intergumentary System (skin, hair, scales, feathers, hooves, and nails).
Endocrine system (hormones/glands that regulate various functions)
Feedback systems (positive/negative).  Note these may be highly correlated with the endocrine system above.
Transpiration (water movement through plants from roots to leaves/stems/flowers)

column5: Cellular Biology (bacteria, single vs multicellular, cell theory)

column6: Single vs Multicellular / Prokarotic vs Eukaryotic Cells
Cell Theory (all living organisms composed of cells, cell is the basic unit of structure and organization of organisms, cells arise from preexisting cells)
Animal Cells (Overall structure/functioning of animal cells)
Plant Cells (Overall structure/functioning of plant cells)
Generic cell reproduction (cell cycle), not tied to meiosis/mitosis (note: refactor later after annotation complete to have meiosis/mitosis as categories under this?)
Meiosis (Cellular reproduction of germ/sex cells only)
Mitosis (Cellular reproduction of body/somatic cells, but not germ/sex cells)
Proteins and components (e.g. amino acids, peptide bonds)
Reproduction of Bacteria and Viruses (or generally, non-plant, non-animal cells)
Levels of Organization of Living Things

column3: Human Health (Humans need a variety of healthy foods, exercise, and rest in order to grow and maintain good health)

column4: Good and Bad Health Habits (hand washing and personal cleanliness; avoiding harmful substances, e.g., including alcohol, tobacco, illicit drugs; eating a balanced diet)

column3: Development and the Environment (The health, growth, and development of organisms are affected by environmental conditions such as the availability of food, air, water, space, shelter, heat, and sunlight)

column4: Environmental effects on plants (e.g. droughts, floods)

column3: Responses to Immediate Environmental Changes

column4: Plants and their Environment (Plants respond to changes in their environment. For example, the leaves of some green plants change position as the direction of light changes)
Animals and their Environment (Animals respond to change in their environment, e.g., perspiration, heart rate, breathing rate, eye blinking, shivering, and salivating, finding shelter when it rains)

column3: Extinction

column4: Mass extinction (events, causes, etc. -- e.g. asteroid impacts)

column3: Lab safety equipment (e.g. goggles, gloves, aprons, etc)
Safety Procedures (e.g. talking to the teacher if you spill chemicals or break items)
Components of Scientific Inference (hypothesis, experiments, observation/data collection, interpretation)

column4: Generic/Step Ordering (e.g. hypothesis comes before experiment)
Sample Size (the higher the sample size, the more stable the result)
Figuring out what an experiment being described is testing (e.g. a student performs experiment X.... what was it designed to test?)
Identifying testable (or, easily testable) predictions.  (i.e., what are questions that can be answered by science?)

column3: Graphical Communication of Data (i.e. what graph would be appropriate to communicate a given kind of data)
Sources for scientific information (e.g. a scientific journal article vs a newspaper article, or an opinion from someone)
Developing explicit models of a process
Other

column3: Inventions and their impact

column2: Instructions (reading instructions is required to build something)
Device use that does not involve the topic of energy
